channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fresh Shelling at Nuclear Plant in Southern Ukraine Deepens Grave Safety Concerns
item.description: As shelling continued at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, the U.N. secretary general, António Guterres, said he was “gravely concerned” the hostilities might lead to a disaster. Satellite images show Russia lost at least eight warplanes in blasts at a Crimean air base on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Partners With Oil Companies
item.description: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gas flame burned at an oil well in Putumayo, Colombia.

item.title: Erdogan and Putin: Complicated Relations With Mutual Benefits
item.description: Turkey needs Russian cash, gas and business as Erdogan looks to a dicey election and a new incursion in Syria, while Moscow needs friends to try to evade Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Murat Kula/Turkish Presidential Press Service via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meeting with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Sochi, Russia, last week.

item.title: Palestinian Prisoners in Israel Use Hunger Strikes to Seek Freedom
item.description: For decades, Palestinians imprisoned by Israel have used these protests as a way to demand better living conditions and an end to indefinite detentions.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kayed al-Fasfos at his home in the West Bank in April. He was released from an Israeli prison after a 131-day hunger strike. “Even if I had died,” he said, “I would consider it a victory because in the end I left the prison.”

item.title: U.S. Urges Rwanda and Congo to End Support for Warring Militias
item.description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said he had warned the leaders of both nations over violence in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Andrew Harnik
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken visited the Kigali Genocide Memorial in Rwanda on Thursday. Backing militias, he said, was “likely to perpetuate conflict and violence.”

item.title: Rishi Sunak Has a Sterling Résumé. It’s Not Helping Him Replace Boris Johnson.
item.description: Mr. Sunak is viewed by many in his party as too distant from ordinary Britons, and is being blamed by some for setting off the rebellion that toppled Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Chris J Ratcliffe/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, center, spoke to people in Ropley, England, last month as part of his campaign to become leader of the Conservative Party and the next prime minister.

item.title: Fires Rip Through France Amid New Heat Wave
item.description: In the southwest, a blaze that started in July has reignited because of the heat and the dry air, scorching an additional 26 square miles of bushes and forest.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Thibaud Moritz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Farmers near Belin-Beliet, France, tried to help put out a fire overnight Thursday.

item.title: From the Workshop to the War: Creative Use of Drones Lifts Ukraine
item.description: While Russia lacks an effective long-range strike drone, Ukraine’s experimentation has produced an array of inexpensive, plastic aircraft, jury-rigged to drop grenades or other munitions.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times

item.title: Kenyans Await Results as Votes Are Counted in Presidential Race
item.description: Conflicting estimates of which candidate was ahead suggested a very tight race. Official results are expected to take several days.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Monicah Mwangi/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers and polling workers sorting sealed ballot boxes on Wednesday in Nairobi.

item.title: London Plans Polio Vaccine Boosters as More Virus Is Found in Sewage
item.description: Children of ages 1 to 9 in the city will be offered a booster after signs that the virus was turning up more frequently in samples. No cases have so far been reported.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Tower of London was lit up purple to mark World Polio Day last year. Britain’s last known polio case was in 1984.

item.title: ‘We Couldn’t Do Anything’: Family Drowns in Seoul Basement During Floods
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of poor people live in semi-underground homes around the city. The death of a family of three showed ​how vulnerable they are to flooding.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: The stairs to a semi-underground home in Seoul, where two women and a 13-year-old girl died on Monday after heavy floods.

item.title: The Marcos Family Gets Star Treatment in a New Philippines Film
item.description: A big-budget production depicts the family as victims of a political vendetta, a popular narrative during the recent presidential election in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Imee Marcos, sister of president Ferdinand Marcos Jr., attending the premiere of “Maid in Malacanang,” for which she was the executive producer.

item.title: In Italy, Where Pizza Was Born, Domino’s Bows Out
item.description: The company entered the Italian market in 2015, but seems to have been done in by a proliferation of home-delivery food during the pandemic and a desire for more artisanal pies.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Lucy Nicholson/Reuters
item.media:description: A Domino’s pizza. The company’s Italian franchise has extinguished its pizza ovens in the country where pizza was invented.

item.title: New Laws in Sierra Leone Reshape Environmental Battleground
item.description: The West African nation will let communities veto mining, farming and industrial projects. Activists say the legislation is a progressive landmark. At least one investor calls it unworkable.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Cooper Inveen/Reuters
item.media:description: Independent diamond miners just outside a mining concession in Sierra Leone in March. Farming and mining companies have often failed to consult local communities about their projects.

item.title: You Just Can’t Get the Staff
item.description: Australia’s labor and skills shortage has affected almost every sector. Signs of it are everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Isabella Moore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Sydney earlier this year. Australia’s labor and skills shortage has affected almost every sector, including food service.

item.title: How Sri Lankans Rose Up to Dethrone a Dynasty
item.description: An army of nuns, farmers and middle-class professionals felt a duty to save their virtually bankrupt nation. But their fight is far from over.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal, Emily Schmall and Atul Loke
item.media:credit: Atul Loke For The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters celebrating last month in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after the resignation of President Gotabaya Rajapaksa.

item.title: Greece’s Mitsotakis Fends Off Accusations His Government Spied on Rivals
item.description: Revelations that the cellphone of a top opposition politician was tapped have shaken the government and stoked concerns over just how widespread such surveillance is.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:credit: Thanassis Stavrakis/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece in May. His government has been accused of spying on its political rivals.

item.title: U.N. Ship to Carry Ukrainian grain Directly to Horn of Africa
item.description: It is the first ship hired to carry the grain to countries badly affected by food shortages since a deal between Ukraine and Russia allowed shipments to resume.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain silos at the Odesa Port in Odesa, Ukraine, in July.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Moves by the U.S. to unseal the Mar-a-Lago search warrant.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland.

item.title: Serbia’s Leader Rejects Putin Label Amid Fears of Russian Meddling
item.description: President Aleksandar Vucic’s ties to Moscow raise awkward questions as the Kremlin appears to be stirring unrest in the Balkans to deflect attention from the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Aleksandar Vucic in the library of the presidential palace in Belgrade, the Serbian capital, this month. “We are not interested in expanding our borders and getting into any fights with our neighbors,” he said.

item.title: Shelling Threatens Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant, and U.N. Pleads for Access
item.description: The chief U.N. nuclear monitor called for an immediate stop to fighting that risks a radiation disaster, as Russians and Ukrainians blamed each other for strikes dangerously close to the reactors.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas and Shashank Bengali
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A Russian military convoy on the road to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant in May.

item.title: How the war changed a Kyiv museum’s view of its past.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: Heavy Losses Leave Russia Short of Its Goal, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The estimated deaths and injuries are stalling Russia’s progress in eastern Ukraine, military experts say, as fighting intensifies in the south.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of a tank in the Chernihiv region of Ukraine. U.S. officials estimate that 500 Russian troops are killed or wounded every day in Ukraine.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. to Unseal Trump Warrant
item.description: Plus Russia prepares for show trials and Taiwan does not rise to China’s provocations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland had come under pressure to provide more information about the search at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home.

item.title: Rhythm of War: A Thunderous Blast, and Then a Coffee Break
item.description: This is a war fought in a cycle of opposites: bursts of chaos from outgoing and incoming shelling, and then long lulls in which soldiers undertake the most routine activities.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian artillery unit firing from a frontline position near the town of Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Don’t Blame Monkeys for Monkeypox, W.H.O. Says After Attacks
item.description: The outbreak is centered on humans, not animals, health officials said, after a report that some monkeys were harmed in São Paulo, Brazil, out of fear of transmission, according to local authorities.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Marcelo Sayo/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A monkey at Lage Park in Rio de Janeiro. At least 10 monkeys were rescued in São Paulo, Brazil, after they appeared to have been attacked or poisoned, the police there said.

item.title: All Hooting Aside: Did a Vocal Evolution Give Rise to Language?
item.description: The loss of certain muscles in the human larynx may have helped give our species a voice, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang
item.media:credit: Nature Picture Library/Alamy
item.media:description: A study of more than three dozen primates found that they all possessed an extra set of vocal membranes in the larynx, just above the vocal cords. Only humans lack the structure.

item.title: Italy Salutes a War Hero and the Values He Fought For
item.description: Mario Fiorentini, Italy’s most decorated resistance fighter, died at age 103 this week, and his mourners want his legacy to live on.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Fiorentini family
item.media:description: Mr. Fiorentini when he was in his 20s.

item.title: The New ‘Monuments Officers’ Prepare to Protect Art Amid War
item.description: A group of art experts have had intensive training to become part of the U.S. Army Reserve. It will be their job to help save cultural heritage in war zones.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Army’s Monuments Officers in training. They will work in a military capacity to identify and preserve cultural treasures around the world that are threatened by conflict, just like the Monuments Men of World War II.

item.title: A Moscow court places a former state television journalist under house arrest over her anti-war protest.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Natalia Kolesnikova/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Marina Ovsyannikova, who was detained and fined after protesting the war on television in March, has been sentenced to house arrest over her protest outside the Kremlin in July.

item.title: Arctic Warming 4 Times as Fast as the Rest of the Planet, New Analyses Find
item.description: The warming at the top of the globe, a sign of climate change, is happening much faster than previously described compared with the global average, scientists said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Kerem Yucel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An iceberg from the Greenland ice sheet near Pituffik, Greenland, last month.

item.title: Rethinking Joe Manchin
item.description: Now that Joe Manchin has saved the Democratic agenda, how should liberals think about him?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin on Capitol Hill last week.

item.title: China Vows More Drills, but Taiwan Is Undeterred
item.description: China’s drills have hardened Taiwan’s understated approach to navigating a big-power rivalry over its political future.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A live-fire drill in Pingtung, Taiwan, on Tuesday. The Taiwanese military said it would not escalate after Chinese military drills in the region.

item.title: North Korea’s Covid Outbreak Is Over, Kim Jong-un Says
item.description: Kim Jong-un declared “victory” over the virus, despite a lack of vaccines. Outside experts have cast doubt on the North’s pandemic-related claims.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kim Won Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, in late July. North Korea claimed to have no Covid-19 cases until May, when it announced its first outbreak.

item.title: Zelensky addresses the explosions in Crimea as photos suggest a major loss for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Damage from a blast in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: The Jan. 6 attack was a crisis. So why wasn’t it more of a scandal?
item.description: The political dog that didn’t bark.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters storming the Senate side of the U.S. Capitol after a rally where President Trump spoke on Jan. 6 last year.

item.title: Crimean Officials Detail Size of Explosions, Contradicting Kremlin
item.description: Blasts at an air base in the Russian-occupied territory damaged 62 apartment buildings and forced hundreds into shelters. Satellite imagery showed destroyed fighter jets.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Alan Yuhas and Christiaan Triebert
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Beachgoers in Novofedorivka, in Russian-occupied Crimea, were initially startled by an explosion at a nearby Russian military air base on Tuesday.

item.title: Families of Israelis Killed at Munich Olympics Plan Anniversary Boycott
item.description: The families of the athletes killed by the Black September terrorist group say that the compensation they have been offered is inadequate and will stay away from a ceremony in Munich in September.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Maya Alleruzzo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ankie Spitzer, at her home in Israel last month, held a framed photo of her husband, Andrei, who was killed in the 1972 attack.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Trump Declines to Answer Questions
item.description: Plus new details about explosions in Crimea and revelations about the victims of Seoul’s floods.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former president Donald J. Trump leaves Trump Tower in New York, on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia Detains a Former Journalist Who Protested the War
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Alexander Zemlianichenko/Associated Press
item.media:description: Marina Ovsyannikova, a former state television employee, during a court hearing in Moscow last month.

item.title: Ukraine’s experimentation with drones gives it a technological advantage.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder

item.title: Sentence of American Lawyer Held in U.A.E. Is Overturned
item.description: The man, Asim Ghafoor — who was convicted in absentia of financial crimes and had once worked with Jamal Khashoggi — is expected to be released.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/ The New York Times
item.media:description: Asim Ghafoor, left, in Washington in 2008. His punishment raised the alarm that he was being targeted for political reasons, but U.A.E officials say his case was about financial wrongdoing.

item.title: Hungary Settles Russia’s Bill With Ukraine to Restore Oil Flows
item.description: Hungary’s energy conglomerate, MOL, paid Russia’s transit fees to Ukraine, ensuring that oil keeps flowing through an overland pipeline that remains crucial for Central Europe.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Anna Szilagyi/Associated Press
item.media:description: An MOL gas station in Budapest on Wednesday.

item.title: Justice Dept. Charges Iranian in Plot to Kill John Bolton
item.description: Prosecutors said a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps sought the murder of the former national security adviser in retaliation for the killing of a top Iranian official.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Jonathan Drake/Reuters
item.media:description: John R. Bolton was subject of a plot by a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps to be assassinated, according to the Justice Department.

item.title: U.S. Presses Congo to Slow Oil-and-Gas Push in Rainforests
item.description: The secretary of state’s efforts led to the U.S. and the Democratic Republic of Congo agreeing to have a team look at environmental conservation.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Andrew Harnik
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Foreign Minister Christophe Lutundula of the Democratic Republic of Congo in the country’s capital, Kinshasa, on Tuesday. They discussed land auctions and the rainforest.

item.title: Gary Schroen, Who Led the C.I.A. Into Afghanistan, Dies at 80
item.description: Weeks before the troops arrived, he took a small team into the country to prepare for an invasion and begin the hunt for Osama bin Laden.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Alex Wong/Getty Images
item.media:description: The former C.I.A. officer Gary C. Schroen on the NBC News program “Meet the Press” in 2005, speaking about his book “First In: An Insider’s Account of How the C.I.A. Spearheaded the War on Terror in Afghanistan.”

item.title: Beluga Whale Dies in France During Last-Ditch Rescue Mission
item.description: The 13-foot, 1,800-pound animal had been removed from the Seine river where it had been stranded for days, but it was later euthanized after experiencing difficulty breathing.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Jean-Francois Monier/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers trying to help the stranded beluga whale in an overnight operation. The animal’s fate had garnered attention beyond France.

item.title: Months after Russian soldiers withdrew, Bucha begins to bury its unidentified dead.
item.dc:creator: Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Russian propaganda is spreading in Spanish and Arabic and in places outside the West.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Exhuming the remains of a family from a makeshift grave at a church in Bucha, Ukraine, in April. Some non-English sites spread a Russian spin that portrays atrocities in Bucha as exaggerations or hoaxes.

item.title: Two Trump Scenarios
item.description: What should you make of the F.B.I.’s search of Donald Trump’s home? We offer a guide.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump at a rally last month.

item.title: U.S. Insists It Will Operate Around Taiwan, Despite China’s Pressure
item.description: The confrontation threatens to overwhelm President Biden’s efforts to find a series of issues in which the United States and China can work together.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ben Dooley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Annabelle Chih/Getty Images
item.media:description: Taiwanese soldiers firing artillery during a drill in Pingtung, Taiwan, on Wednesday in response to China's live-fire exercises in waters close to those claimed by the island.

item.title: These Groups Want Disruptive Climate Protests. Oil Heirs Are Funding Them.
item.description: Beneficiaries of two American oil fortunes are supporting groups trying to block fossil fuel projects. One donor said he felt a “moral obligation.”
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters from the group Just Stop Oil in London last month. The organization received almost $1 million from the Climate Emergency Fund, helping to cover salaries for 40 organizers and activists.

item.title: A tally of damage near a Crimean air base contradicts the Kremlin’s assertions.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rose near a Russian air base near Novofedorivka in Crimea on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia’s grip on Ukrainian cyberspace.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: As of June, the war had destroyed or damaged about 15 percent of Ukraine's internet structure, including these cables being repaired in Irpin, near Kyiv.

item.title: Explosions Rip Through Russian Base on Crimea
item.description: A senior Ukrainian official said his country’s forces were responsible, which Ukraine did not publicly confirm or deny. Russian officials said only that munitions had detonated.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: Smoke rising after explosions near a Russian military air base in Crimea on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Weighing ‘Final’ E.U. Offer on Nuclear Deal
item.description: Tehran has dropped a key demand that stalled the talks for months, but it now has a new one.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Steven Erlanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Presidency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Ebrahim Raisi of Iran visiting an exhibition of Iran's nuclear achievements in Tehran in April.

item.title: Voting Is Over in Kenya’s Election. Here’s What Comes Next.
item.description: The two front-runners for the presidency — one making his fifth attempt — said victory was within reach. But a dispute over the results seems inevitable, and the next phase could be turbulent.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir

item.title: Russia Launches Iranian Satellite, a Sign of Closer Cooperation
item.description: Iran says the satellite’s powerful camera is not meant for military purposes, but some experts say it will greatly enhance Tehran’s intelligence gathering.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar, Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Roscosmos, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image from a video released by Roscosmos, Russia’s space agency, on Tuesday reportedly showed a Russian rocket carrying an Iranian satellite into orbit.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The F.B.I. Searches Donald Trump’s Home
item.description: Also, a deadly flood in Seoul and a tense presidential election in Kenya.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump supporters driving in front of Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Fla., on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Signs Measures Giving Approval to Sweden and Finland’s Bids to Join NATO
item.description: The expansion of NATO has received overwhelming support among Democrats and Republicans in a deeply divided Washington.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden signed a measure on Tuesday that would add Sweden and Finland to NATO. All 30 current members of the alliance must approve of the addition of the two countries.
